nodes.text: Government debt (external and internal) changes the long-run competitive equilibrium in a neoclassical two-period overlapping-generations growth model and thereby affects the lifetime utility of individuals in that equilibrium

Method: Model setup uses discrete time overlapping generations (individuals live two periods), constant returns to scale production F(K,L) written as L f(k), no depreciation, one- period government debt, lump-sum taxes on the young, and a constant debt-labor ratio (debt grows at population rate n)

Claim: The competitive equilibrium of this model can be dynamically inefficient: the equilibrium interest rate r may be different from the population growth rate n so that capital-labor ratio can exceed the Golden Rule level

Claim: External government debt affects the domestic economy solely via the taxes required to finance interest payments (which reduce net wages, disposable income, savings, and thus capital stock) and thereby shifts the saving schedule and the locus of equilibrium interest rates

Claim: Internal government debt has the same tax effect as external debt plus an additional portfolio substitution effect that replaces physical capital with government debt in private portfolios, further reducing the capital stock and output

Result/Evidence: In the normal efficient case where r > n, externally held debt reduces the utility of an individual in long-run equilibrium because taxes lower lifetime consumption and the induced reduction in capital raises the equilibrium interest rate away from the Golden Rule

Result/Evidence: In the normal efficient case internal debt causes an even larger decline in individual long-run utility than external debt because it combines tax effects with the substitution of government debt for physical capital, lowering output and welfare further

Claim/Qualification: If the competitive solution is dynamically inefficient (r < n), the signs of welfare effects from issuing debt (external or internal) can reverse and may increase utility; hence effects are ambiguous in the inefficient case

Method/Approach: Differential incidence analysis is used â€” compare financing a given government expenditure by debt versus taxes and analyze long-run equilibrium locus changes (i1 curve shifts) and resulting changes in r, w, k and utility

Evidence/Result: Analytical equilibrium conditions (capital market: r_{t+1}=f'(s(w_t - (r_t - n)g, r_{t+1})/(1+n)); factor-price frontier w = f(k)-kf'(k)) imply taxes lower saving, shift the saving schedule, and thereby change the equilibrium wage-interest pair; implicit differentiation shows dr/dg has sign of (r - n)

Result/Claim: Replacing external debt by internal debt (a debt swap) raises the equilibrium interest rate (government enters domestic demand for funds) and thus reduces the capital-labor ratio; in the efficient case this lowers utility, while in the inefficient case the welfare sign is ambiguous and depends on parameter magnitudes

Limitation: Conclusions rely on modeling assumptions (no depreciation, two-period lifetimes, lump-sum taxes on the young, one-period debt, perfect certainty, constant returns production, constant debt-labor ratio) which restrict generality and may affect quantitative and some qualitative results

Context: Extends Modigliani by incorporating individual intertemporal consumption choices, explicit taxes to finance interest, and recognition of output changes from capital stock shifts; relates to Samuelson on consumption-loan model and Golden Rule literature

Claim/Evidence: Diagrammatic and algebraic analysis decomposes welfare effects into (a) tax-financing effects that reduce disposable lifetime consumption and savings and (b) allocation effects via changed factor prices from altered capital stock; both can be quantified via derived dU/dg expressions

Conclusion: Overall, in the standard 'normal' case (competitive solution efficient, r > n) both external and internal debt lower long-run individual utility and substituting internal for external debt worsens welfare; in the inefficient case results are ambiguous and can reverse
